<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 280, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 544, 293]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 235, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 599, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 416]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 505]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 534]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 549]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 696, 104, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 695, 719, 714]]<|/det|>
When the volcano Krakatoa erupted in 1883, it was heard 5000 km away.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 725, 663, 744]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the sound from the volcano is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 754, 133, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 754, 922, 789]]<|/det|>
If such a loud sound were to be made today, an astronaut orbiting in space (a vacuum) at a height of \(400\mathrm{km}\) could hear it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 794, 131, 813]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 794, 880, 814]]<|/det|>
People further from the volcano heard the sound later than people nearer to the volcano.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 821, 131, 839]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 821, 856, 841]]<|/det|>
The amplitude of the sound waves would have been smaller further from the volcano.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 847, 133, 866]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 847, 880, 866]]<|/det|>
The sound was very loud because a lot of energy was transferred to vibrations of the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 808, 91]]<|/det|> A loudspeaker on a boat produces a pulse of sound in the sea. The echo of the pulse <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 85, 730, 106]]<|/det|> back at the boat after 3.0 s. The depth of the sea under the boat is 2250 m. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[344, 112, 650, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 672, 317]]<|/det|> From this information, what is the speed of sound in the sea water? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 737, 346]]<|/det|> A 330 m/s B 750 m/s C 1500 m/s D 6750 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 371, 104, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 371, 527, 389]]<|/det|> How can a permanent magnet be demagnetised? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 400, 136, 419]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 400, 411, 419]]<|/det|> cool the magnet for a long time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 427, 134, 445]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 427, 492, 445]]<|/det|> hit the magnet repeatedly with a hammer <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 453, 134, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 453, 626, 472]]<|/det|> leave the magnet in a coil which is connected to a battery <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 479, 131, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 479, 432, 497]]<|/det|> shine bright light onto the magnet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 522, 104, 541]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 522, 685, 541]]<|/det|> A hard magnetic material can be used to make a permanent magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 553, 672, 571]]<|/det|> A soft magnetic material can be used to make a temporary magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 583, 755, 601]]<|/det|> Which row shows whether iron and steel are hard or soft magnetic materials? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 351, 743]]<|/det|>
ironsteel
Ahardhard
Bhardsoft

Dsoftsoft

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 808, 106]]<|/det|> A radioactive substance emits a particle from the nucleus of one of its atoms. consists of two protons and two neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 115, 400, 135]]<|/det|> What is the name of this process? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 139, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 145, 248, 163]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \)-emission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 172, 139, 191]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 172, 245, 191]]<|/det|> \(\beta \)-emission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 200, 139, 218]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 200, 243, 218]]<|/det|> \(\gamma \)-emission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 227, 139, 245]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 227, 275, 244]]<|/det|> nuclear fission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 272, 106, 290]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 272, 490, 290]]<|/det|> A nucleus X has 17 protons and 18 neutrons. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 301, 463, 319]]<|/det|> Which notation is correct for this nucleus? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 330, 175, 349]]<|/det|> \(^{17}_{8}\mathrm{X}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 330, 306, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 330, 344, 349]]<|/det|> \(^{17}_{35}\mathrm{X}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 330, 490, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 330, 522, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 330, 541, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 330, 636, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 330, 693, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[653, 330, 693, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[656, 330, 693, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 380, 136, 399]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 380, 695, 399]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a cathode-ray tube used to produce cathode rays. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 408, 885, 623]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 634, 655, 653]]<|/det|> Which change would increase the deflection of the cathode rays? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 134, 681]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 662, 475, 681]]<|/det|> decreasing the current \(I\) in the filament <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 133, 708]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 691, 470, 708]]<|/det|> increasing the current \(I\) in the filament <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 717, 131, 735]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 717, 732, 735]]<|/det|> increasing the potential difference between the filament and the anode <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 743, 133, 761]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 743, 645, 761]]<|/det|> increasing the potential difference between the metal plates <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 878, 920, 911]]<|/det|> Permission to reproduce items where third-party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible.
